channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: The Man Who Sold His Fate For $1 A Share
item.description: Mike Merrill decided to sell himself on the open market. He divided himself into 100,000 shares and set an initial public offering price of $1 a share. Then he let his new stockholders determine what he should do with his life.

item.title: What Happens If North Korea Collapses?
item.description: Pyongyang is threatening nuclear war. But that might not even be the worst-case scenario.

item.title: What's The Safest Seat On An Airplane?
item.description: If you're unlucky enough to be involved in a plane crash, hopefully you're lucky enough to be in this seat.

item.title: Here's How To Take An Entire Continent Offline... With An Axe
item.description: At its peak, Cyberbunker clogged up a mind-boggling 300 gigabits per second of the Internet in what’s being called the biggest cyber-attack in history. But what if you could switch off 1.28 terabits—four times as much bandwidth—with nothing more high-tech than an axe?

item.title: Why The Gay-Marriage Fight Is Over
item.description: This is what I will remember about the atmosphere at the Supreme Court during the same-sex marriage cases: that it wasn’t terribly memorable.

item.title: New Discovery About The Speed Of Light
item.description: Can you trust nothing in life? A new physics paper suggests that the speed of light in a vacuum may not be constant, and that a vacuum isn't actually entirely empty of stuff.

item.title: How I Helped The Biggest DDoS Of All Time
item.description: I contributed to the massive DDOS attack against Spamhaus. What flowed through my network wasn't huge - it averaged 500Kbit/sec – but it contributed. And it was all because of a simple error.

item.title: 25 Highly Accurate Comics About The Internet
item.description: Not sure whether to laugh or cry.

item.title: Bitcoin Prices Have Gone Utterly Nuclear In The Last Two Days
item.description: The price of a Bitcoin, the digital money that's become the new obsession of gold and silver-types, continues its dizzying assent.

item.title: Real-Life Tatooine Captured In A Photo
item.description: Exoplanet hunters may have bagged the first direct picture of a planet with two suns.

item.title: How The Internet Is Making Us Poor
item.description: Everyone knows the story of how robots replaced humans on the factory floor. But in the broader sweep of automation versus labor, a trend with far greater significance for the middle class—in rich countries, at any rate—has been relatively overlooked: the replacement of knowledge workers with software.

item.title: Ryan Gosling And Charlize Theron Courted For Oscar Pistorius Biopic
item.description: Per a report in The Daily Mail, Gosling “has been approached” to play South African Olympian Oscar Pistorius—who fatally shot his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp this past Valentine’s Day—in an upcoming film.

item.title: How Sock Thieves Go To Prison For Life And Wall Street Crooks Get Off Easy
item.description: While Wall Street crooks walk, thousands sit in California prisons for life over crimes as trivial as stealing socks.

item.title: The Incredible Tale Of A 1909 Fight To The Death Inside A Moving Elevator
item.description: An account from the paper of record of a fatal fight that raged as the elevator flew up and down the shaft.

item.title: Apple Patenting Futuristic iPhone With Wrap-Around Display And Seamless Glass Housing
item.description: In a patent filing published by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office on Thursday, Apple describes a futuristic portable device complete with wrap-around AMOLED display, all-glass construction and face tracking.

item.title: Every Videogame From The Simpsons
item.description: In his time as a 10-year-old, Bart Simpson has lived through seven generations of videogames.

item.title: How 'Game Of Thrones' Makes Its Fashion
item.description: If you’re in the North, you don’t have access to a lot of cloths that they do in King’s Landing, so you look very much within the radius of what’s there, which is furs and wools and rather murky dyes.

item.title: High Schoolers Create Amazing One-Take Mashup Video
item.description: The Highland Trouveres assembled an 8 minute mashup. Then they shot it all in one astounding take.

item.title: American Gangsters Suck At The Internet
item.description: A Google Ideas-funded study found that American street gang members use the Internet mainly for self-promotion and posting YouTube videos.

item.title: Online Dating For People With STDs Becoming A Thing
item.description: Dating can often be fraught with uncertainty and self-consciousness. For those with incurable sexually transmitted infections (STIs), are tailored websites the answer for people nervous of telling potential partners about their condition?

item.title: NSA Declassifies Its Super-Secret Internal Magazine
item.description: Today the NSA declassified about a quarter-century’s worth of back issues of its super-secret, in-house technical journal, written by and for agency employees.

item.title: Is Giving The Secret To Getting Ahead?
item.description: The organizational psychologist Adam Grant argues that the key to success is tirelessly helping others.

item.title: The Ancient Origins Of Autocorrect
item.description: The iPhone's funniest feature owes a lot to Microsoft. Here's what autocorrect looked like in 1993.

item.title: A Mural Made From 85,794 Rubik's Cubes
item.description: The rubik’s cubes were meticulously arranged one at a time to create the 200 foot long 13 foot tall image, taking months to complete

item.title: I Controlled A Video Game With My Mind
item.description: Put on this headset. Now throw that truck using nothing more than your thoughts.

item.title: 21 Fun, Obscure Facts About The Cast Of 'Game Of Thrones'
item.description: Hopefully, some of these still have the ability to surprise (I know that a few of them knocked me on my ass), while some others may only be of interest to those coming into the show relatively recently.

item.title: What The Future Of Advertising On Google Glass Might Look Like
item.description: But it's not hard to imagine Google Glass going mainstream a few years for now, sporting a much more affordable price tag that's made possible by ads.

item.title: Who's The Most Powerful Woman In The World?
item.description: Hint: It's not Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg. She lives in Berlin and is key to solving the euro crisis.

item.title: 7 Of The Oldest Food Finds
item.description: Food rots fast. Therefore it is cause for great history-nerd celebration when archeologists dig up food preserved centuries past its expiration date. Here are seven of the most venerable victuals.

item.title: TSA Agent Confuses Pepper Spray With Laser Pointer, With Comic Results
item.description: The latest installment in the popular "TSA Follies."

item.title: Journalist Takes Truck For Test Drive, Truck Burns To A Crisp In 3 Minutes
item.description: "For a few hours last week, my copper-colored Ram pickup cruised the plains of North Texas like some overdressed Duke of Dallas...it all disappeared in a thick column of acrid brown smoke on the side of the Dallas North Tollway — $54,335 worth of truck gone in about three minutes."
